Award.AwardTitle: Making the Difference: An Industrial Engineering Capstone Design Experience to Benefit Adults with Disabilities

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal: 1403753
PI: Mendez-Pinero, Mayra I.
Title: Making the Difference: An Industrial Engineering Capstone Design Experience to Benefit Adults with Disabilities

Adults with disabilities have numerous special needs and engineers have the potential to make great contributions and improve their quality of life. The Department of Industrial Engineering at the University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez (IE-UPRM) proposes to provide a team based design experience for senior Industrial Engineering (IE) students focusing on outreach to aid adults with disabilities and the visually impaired. To achieve the proposed objective, the design projects will be developed at several nonprofit institutions that offer services or provides employment for the groups of interest. Ten design projects have been identified in collaboration with the institutions to design and implement prototypes that will foster independence and self-care, improve the safety and quality of life of individuals with disabilities, augment their functional capabilities, develop and enhance therapeutic devices, and increase productivity for the blind or visually impaired workers.

Technical Description
Typical IE Capstone design projects are usually focused on service or manufacturing industries. Rarely, students focus on projects proposed herein. Students will have the opportunity to interact with health care professionals and expand their understanding on the contribution IEs can have on the quality of life of humanity. Students will also have the opportunity to increase their knowledge in the legal and ethical issues related to the design process. New knowledge developed through these experiences will have an impact on other communities by dissemination of results through presentations, conferences, etc. This will convey the message and it should have an impact on the process used by engineering universities in their planning of the capstone course project strategies. The research team teaches various courses requiring applied design projects and possesses ample experience supervising and mentoring undergraduate students while conducting projects in the island. As a result of the internal logistics of the IE Capstone Course, the department contains the infrastructure and collaboration network needed to support the proposed research projects. A key component of this proposal is the incorporation of multiple formative and summative assessment activities to evaluate the individual project success, student gains in experience and knowledge, and success of the proposed work.

With the Design Projects students will develop technical and professional skills to be prepared for the practice of the profession; develop awareness and consider ethical, legal, and societal issues relevant to a design project; complement the educational process with real life problem solving experience and integrate the principles, methods, and techniques of earlier course work into a problem solving situation. Students will gain awareness, sensibility and knowledge on the needs of adults with disabilities, broadening their IE knowledge. With three projects to be run each year the impact will be magnified as participating students will share their projects in the classroom with their colleagues and the community. As a minority serving institution, the proposed projects will broaden the participation of Hispanic undergraduate students in research activities. In order to broaden dissemination to enhance scientific and technological understanding, results from this research work will be disseminated through presentations at national conferences as well as in the departmental website, the Puerto Rico Assistive Technology Program, campus news and local news forums. Additional websites to share the results are: the Office of Disability Employment Policy, Disability.gov, and the National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “Making the Difference: An Industrial Engineering Capstone Design Experience to Benefit Adults with Disabilities”, summarized herein had a significant impact on students at the Industrial Engineering Program at the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez (ININ at UPRM), on participating organizations and population of adults with disabilities, and on the strategy used on the capstone design course.

The Industrial Engineering Capstone design projects at UPRM usually focused on the service or manufacturing industry. This project had an impact on the focus of design projects by highlighting an area of research work where industrial engineers at UPRM seldom focused and created awareness of the population of adults with disabilities and the significant effect engineers can have on this population. All eleven projects completed under this research project focused on the design of prototypes to foster independence and self-care, improve the safety and quality of life of individuals with disabilities, augment their functional capabilities, and/or develop and enhance therapeutic devices.

Instruction manuals and blueprints were developed for all designs. Prototypes were built, assessed and validated with potential users. Normally, capstone design projects at ININ do not go through the construction and validation process due to the course duration of one semester only. Ten out of the eleven (91%) projects completed under this research work used strategy two1, where they perform research work during the first semester and during the second semester they build, assess and validate the artifact; this resulted in students experiencing all design phases up to validation. This is a new approach being seriously considered for the industrial engineering curricular revision at ININ.

As part of this experience students learned to design research protocols for the protection of human beings, strengthened their knowledge in responsible conduct of research through web-based training material offered by the Collaborative Institutional Training Initiative (CITI PROGRAM) at the University of Miami, and project faculty and participating students were certified in the course “Social and Behavioral Research Basic/Refresher”.

Students were instructed on the protection of intellectual property and the process for submitting a Pre-invention Disclosure. All industrial engineering students were given a work shop by the coordinator of the Intellectual Property and Technology Transfer Office (IPTT) of the University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez, ascribed to the College of Engineering. He guided them through the process of protecting intellectual property and as a first step completing a Pre-invention Disclosure Form. This process was completely new to them and created awareness on the relevance of documenting and protecting intellectual property.

The nature of the student projects completed in this research work allowed interaction of students with other disciplines within engineering and the health specialists’ community, expanding their understanding on the contribution industrial engineers can have on the quality of life of humanity, and enhancing their interdisciplinary teamwork and communication skills. Students from mechanical and electrical engineering participated in four of the eleven (36%) projects completed.

There was a significant participation of female students. A total of thirty students participated, where fourteen (47%) were males and sixteen (53%) were females, fulfilling the expectation of increasing participation of females in engineering research work.

Information related to these capstone projects including photos and videos can be found on the website created within the industrial engineering website (http://engineering.uprm.edu/inin/) under the Past Projects tab under Senior Capstone Design Projects to disseminate grant results. Posters documenting the procedure, methodology, and results were created and presented by capstone course students to faculty mentors and supervisors. These were displayed at the industrial engineering building hall where engineering students and the university community in general had access to them. The projects are also highlighted in the Puerto Rico Assistive Technology Program website (http://pratp.upr.edu/servicios/informacion/tecnologias/tecnologias-de-apoyo-a-la-rehabilitacion). A podcast of an interview in “Foro Colegial” to the PI and CoPIs will be available through a podcast in the campus news website (http://www.uprm.edu/p/prensa/foro_colegial).

Doctor Mayra Méndez attended the 5th Annual World Conference of the Society for Industrial and Systems Engineering at San Francisco, CA, held in October 13-14, 2016. A paper titled A Non-Traditional Capstone Design Project Experience for Industrial Engineering Students was presented at the conference and published in the proceedings and can be found at http://ieworldconference.org/content/SISE2016/Mendez-Pinero.pdf.  Doctors Mayra Méndez and Cristina Pomales attended the 2017 ASEE Zone 2 Spring Conference and presented a paper titled Industrial Engineering Students Making a Difference - Capstone Design Projects Impacting Adults with Disabilities. Also, at the same conference five of the seven (75%) projects completed during this year presented posters of their work in process, with the participation of eight out of the eighteen (44%) senior students working on their capstone design projects under this research work. These presentations can be found at http://se.asee.org/proceedings/2017%20Zone%20II%20Proceedings/2017%20Zone%20II.htm.
